name: Daniel
comment info: The first thing I noticed in the graph is practicing social distancing. But have you ever wondered why social distancing became one of our government's method to avoid the spread of Corona Virus? Turns out it's easy to figure it out right? Simply imagine a scenario wherein one person coughs without covering his/her mouth. Automatically,  the droplets with the diseases will be transmitted to you if you don't have a barrier that protects you from it. For example: surgical masks,  and N-95 masks. One of the best ways to also avoid Covid-19 or any other viruses is to have a proper hygiene. Which includes frequently washing your hands and taking 1 or 2 baths everyday. To conclude everything, practicing social distancing can help stop the spread of viruses especially Covid-19. Therefore, in my opinion,  "The Farther, The Safer" is my headline for the graph.

name: Jake S
comment info:
After reading the reveal, the animation in particular stood out to me. All of the mundane tasks that people were staying out of in the animation really showed how much social distancing actually matters. 

It made me think back to last day that nonessential businesses were still open in New Hampshire. I had to get parts for a project I was working on so I took that day to go around and stock up. Everywhere I went, I social distanced as best as possible. One situation in particular stood out to me, though. When I was at Home Depot, a guy was walking towards me down the aisle. Upon seeing each other, we changed which side of the aisle that we were walking on. We were both left, then both right, then both left again, etc. At the time, it was super awkward, but we both laughed it off, knowing what each other was doing.

The reveal makes me think about how, no matter how awkward that situation was, it's entirely possible (if not realistic) that if either of us were carrying the virus we help lessen the load on nearly a hundred people.

name: Victoria Payne
comment info:
When I analyzed the animation, I noticed that when one person stayed home or distanced themselves a whole section of the chain of people being infected after the first person was eliminated off of the chain. When just one person decides to take action and take the precautions that society has been told to follow they have now prevented many others from infection.
When creating the proposed tree graphs for each scenario I noticed that when each person was around three people at stage three there were twenty seven people infected by the end of stage three. When further analyzing the tree graphs I noticed an exponential equation occurring. The equation works by taking the number of people each person is around and raising it to the power of x, the stage that you are solving for, this would give you the number of people infected at the stage plugged in. For example, when each person was around one person you could raise one to the fourth power to find that that at that stage one more person was infected. Another is when each person was around three people you could find three to the power of three would give you twenty seven which is the number of people in stage three that were infected on the tree graph providing evidence for the equation that was built.

Good morning, @Mia --

You are right MIa.  This is a very simple model, but it probably gets across the power of exponential growth, even if the power is only 2.

Sounds like you may benefit from reading the Fivethirtyeight article “Why It’s So Freaking Hard to Make a Good COVID-19 Model (https://tinyurl.com/C19Model).  There, you will read about some of the dozens of assumptions that need to be made to determine the transmission rate and the fatality rate.

name: Arlo
comment info: This graphic provides a clear visual of the role each individual plays in the spread of COVID-19. For every person with whom the infected individual avoids contact, an entire branch of exponential growth is eliminated, greatly reducing the number of people who contract the virus. In the real world, the individual depicted actually wields much more power. This is because the majority of humans have a vast network of people with whom they would typically come in close contact. In the graphic, the removal of one interaction prevents 63 total cases. If we imagine the average person would interact with 10 different people rather than 2, this number jumps to an astounding 111,111. This means that one person limiting their physical contact could prevent a fifth of the population of Wyoming from contracting a life-threatening disease, likely saving over 700 lives. It is important to take into account that these are only potential infections, as not everybody who comes in contact with the disease will be infected. I am curious how long this pattern and rate of spread can continue within a certain region or area, as the entire world population would theoretically be infected by 2^33 (the spread slows eventually). I would like to point out that the WHO recommends the term "physical distancing" over "social distancing", as it's more accurate and doesn't carry the same negative implications of isolation. I would title this graph "The Power of Physical Distancing: How You Can Save Lives".

The first thing I notice is the huge difference there is between the end number of people infected between the two graphs. By just eliminating one person in the chain, you can save many from potentially being infected. Each person goes out and infects two more people, causing this disease to spread exponentially rather than linearly. Social distancing is very important to fighting this disease, and we need to take it seriously. The number of infected people will eventually slow down, but we can make sure that we have the ability to treat all the sick people in the meantime with these preventative measures. If everyone took these lockdowns seriously and only had contact with their immediate family, the effects could be greatly reduced. 

I’ve heard people say that it doesn’t matter if they are just going to hang out with one person. You can’t control the interactions of the people around you, so you just have to control yours and make sure you aren’t unnecessarily putting yourself and others at risk.

name: Cedar S

I notice that a lot fewer people are infected when a person decides to self-isolate. This can be seen by the graph as if both people infected by the red person decide not to self isolate then the potential number of people to be infected (as seen on the graph) is sixty-four. But if one of the two infected people decides to self isolate then the number goes down to thirty-two. If both people decide to self-isolate then the number goes down to two, as in the two self-isolating people. If the original person decides to self-isolate then, the number decreases to one, that person. By each person who decides to self-isolate the number of possible infected people goes down by half.
I wonder if there is any way to avoid the first person getting infected at all? I also wonder if we had handled the initial start of the disease, by immediately starting to self-isolate internationally, how would the numbers have changed? 
A total for this graph could be "How self-isolating decreases the amount of cases."

name: Devon S.
comment info: I notice that this display predicts that every person will spread the virus to two other people. Assuming each dot represents one case of the virus, there happen to be 127 cases in the top half of the display. Each of those cases branched off from one person, which shows that a little leads to a lot in terms of this virus. So what would happen if each person instead spread the virus to three other people? If this were true and the virus multiplied six times like it did in this display, there would be a whopping 1093 total cases of the virus (that's 1+3+3^2+3^3+3^4+3^5+3^6) instead of 127. If everyone spread it to FOUR other people, this number would be 5461. This scares me because it might be possible that many people would spread the virus to three or four other people, since it seems like many people are not staying distant from their friends during these times. This provides strong evidence that staying socially distant from others is very important in times like these, and that all people should be taking social distancing practices seriously, because if both of the first two infections were avoided, this virus chain would have ended at the first person. I wonder if it is really true that each person spreads the virus to only two other people, because it seems like lots of essential workers that cannot work from home would come into contact with many more than two other people over the course of even a day. A catchy headline could be "Social Distancing: Double or Nothing"

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Somya --

You mention people who don’t show signs of coronavirus.  This is called asymptomatic. 
 There is a symptomaticity ratio, which is how many people are symptomatic versus asymptomatic.  From what we know, the ratio may be from ½ to 2/3.   That difference could really change the number of people we expect to contract coronavirus.  Transmission of COVID-19 and its effect is much, much more complicated than these graphs.  
You may want to read the website Fivethirtyeight article “Why It’s So Freaking Hard to Make a Good COVID-19 Model (https://tinyurl.com/C19Model).  There, you will read about some of the dozens of assumptions that need to be made to determine the transmission rate and the fatality rate.  The article is very understandable and gives you diagrams of how the variables interact.

How about sharing a catchy headline that captures what you discovered in your calculations?

name: Moderator
comment info:
Welcome to our moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  Last week, we had a graph that showed how “flattening the curve” could reduce the number of infected people at any one time in our healthcare system.  This week, we have two graphs that show the effect of protective measures on reducing the number of infected people.  

This graph is a tree diagram.  It is a model and is not based on data.  It shows how many people could be infected given some assumptions.  

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas about the graph. 

We encourage students to respond to other students.  We expect teachers to respond to their students as well other students from around the world.

Before Friday, we will reveal the article that included this graph and much more.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Kenneth C --

This is a model.  But, from the scatter plot you studied a month ago, a transmission to 2 people seems about right.  
Let’s take your noticings a step further.  For each of the graphs, make a table with the left column the stage number from 0 – 6 and the right column the number of newly infected people.  What function is represented in this table?  Does this lead you to other wonderings and another headline?
There are many other factors that go into determining the infection rate and the fatality rate.  You may want to read the website Fivethirtyeight article “Why It’s So Freaking Hard to Make a Good COVID-19 Model (https://tinyurl.com/C19Model).  There, you will read about some of the dozens of assumptions that need to be made to determine the transmission rate and the fatality rate.

You can make your own graph.  Here are some assumptions you would want to make.  How many stages would there be?  How many people would a person infect?  Would the number change?  What is the fatality rate of being infected?  How long would a person be infectious.  And, many more.
There are many other factors that go into determining the infection rate and the fatality rate.  You may want to read the website Fivethirtyeight article “Why It’s So Freaking Hard to Make a Good COVID-19 Model (https://tinyurl.com/C19Model).  There, you will read about some of the dozens of assumptions that need to be made to determine the transmission rate and the fatality rate.

name: Maya Honda-Granirer
comment info: I notice that both scenarios in this graph start with merely one person. And after only 6 stages of transmission, 126 individuals are infected with a disease that has a mortality rate double than that of the flu. In other words, it only takes one person to set off an onslaught of disease, destruction, and death. On the other hand, social distancing measures can cut the rate of infection by a whopping half. In the second diagram, where the initial carrier of covid-19 only transmitted the virus to one person instead of two, 63 new individuals are infected, as opposed to 126 from the first diagram. This highlights the dire importance of social distancing in a disease outbreak, such as the one we are currently facing. Every transmission can lead to tens, hundreds and even thousands more. I wonder if this graph represents the person-to-person spread of the virus (through coughing and droplets in the air) only, as opposed to the transmission that can occur when the virus resides on surfaces that people touch. If so, how much worse does it get when the latter type of transmission is factored in? The headline I would choose for this graph is “The Power of One.”

name: Ayush T
comment info:
A common misconception of the ordinary person in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic is that “they are powerless to help control the coronavirus.” People feel unable to contribute to stopping infection because they think no small protective measure can help the millions of researchers, scientists, politicians, and doctors working together day and night. 
This graph, however, shows the power of one prevented infection. In the second depiction, just one avoided infection was enough to prevent another 30 people from getting the coronavirus. Keep in mind that this graph only scratches the scale of the world population; in reality, one avoided infection could theoretically save tens of thousands of people. 
The growth of the coronavirus spread is exponential, and this graph shows how powerful social distancing is. If social distancing was practiced by a majority of the world population for a while, the effects would be tremendous, and would flatten the curve in most countries.

I am a teacher at The Storm King School. I have students from Russia and China. *These are my students' opinions only I understand that there is a mask shortage, and that we should make sure that all hospitals have enough masks before they are available to the general public. Here is their advice or cautionary tales about the virus: 

Alex from Moscow, Russia says: In Russia are only getting worse right now. Quarantine in Moscow starts on Monday the 30th. Right now though, you can see a lot of people without masks and not washing hands. We could prevent the virus by doing simple things.

Sandy from Chengdu, China says: I think people should quarantine at home and prepare to have enough food at home in order to make it through the quarantine. In China, the restaurants closed, and you couldn't even do delivery. People did hoard many of the supplies at the grocery store. They also hoarded masks. The scientists told us that wearing masks could help prevent the spread of the disease. 

Dennis from Shanghai, China says: I think people need to reduce unnecessary outside travel and avoid getting together. If you really need to go out, you must wear a mask to prevent the virus. The most important thing is to wash your hands regularly.
